expectations: You effectively execute tasks assigned to you and keep stakeholders informed of progress and delays.
You own project goals, ensuring appropriate quality, regular stakeholder communication, and on-time delivery.
You work collaboratively with your manager to set realistic yet ambitious short and long-term goals.
You break down goals into smaller projects for you or your team, so progress can be made incrementally.
You're thoughtful about delivering value incrementally and reducing scope where possible.
You set timelines up front and hit them.
You're capable of identifying risks and risk mitigation strategies early in the development of a project, helping ensure their smooth execution.
You set a culture of building right-sized solutions and operating with pace.
You ensure your team is building in a way that brings solutions to market quickly, while making pragmatic design decisions.
You think not just in terms of point-in-time velocity, but long-term velocity.
You own and are accountable for engineering or product objectives requiring novel solutions.
You are an expert at executing on open-ended problems that require difficult prioritization and technical innovation to meet user and business needs.
You own and are accountable for top-level Engineering-wide goals.
You are an expert at driving delivery on projects that require the contributions of multiple teams.
You translate ideas into clear code, written to be read as well as executed.
Your code is free of glaring errors. Bugs are in edge cases or design, not mainline paths.
Your code is well documented or self-documenting (through the use of clear naming).
Your code is well tested with appropriate use of unit and functional tests.
You address code tasks with both high throughput and appropriately high quality for the stage of the project.
You are able to understand the existing designs and technology choices within your area, and you make appropriate adjustments.
You’re able to decompose problems or business scenarios into solutions composed of multiple software components.
You are mastering the skill of written technical communication at an architectural/design altitude.
You proactively identify technical dependencies owned by other teams and surface them.
You not only write clear design docs but also provide quality feedback on designs written by other team members.
You lead efforts to improve documentation, testing, and code skill sharing across teams.
You're capable of designing systems in the face of significant ambiguity.
You’re capable of owning the overall health and engineering quality of a system or collection of features.
You are able to define requirements and drive technical projects across the entire company.
You are capable of representing technology constraints and roadmaps to the executive team.
